Pros_x: Great schedule flexibility and money compared to other restaurants around the city. The place is huge so you can usually get in our out of shifts if you need to, and it stays busy enough that you can make good consistent money (for serving tables).
Cons_x: The Cheesecake Factory unfortunately attracts some extremely undesirable clientele, especially on the weekends. You can see some really really low tip percentages, but usually those shifts come with really high sales, so at the end of the night you still make a good amount of money, but it can be really brutal at times. It's not a place where you do $500 in sales and have a 25% tip percentage, more like $1800 in sales with a 12% tip percentage. Also, the tip out is a total of 4.5% of your sales, which is a bit higher than most places, however in that restaurant you really rely on the help of the rest of your team.
Advice to Management_x: Try to focus more on individual praise. Any time someone does something bad everyone finds out one way or another, but there is not a lot of focus on individual praise. A lot of times the positive feedback is in the form of "hey guys great shift last night" or whatever, instead of pointing people out for great individual performances.
Title_y: "Great for resume. Not for quality of life."
Pros_y: Well respected training program throughout the restaurant community. From staff member positions to managment, they will prepare you for high volume restaurants. Kitchen as well as front of house have many rules and regulations, processes and systems in place, which will out you a cut above the rest when it comes to most aspects of the restaurant industry.
Cons_y: They ask for a mile and will only reward you with an inch. they expect too much at times and rarley come through with promises. the bonus structure is not easily attainable, and even when you do hit every mark, the bonuses are not very substancial.
Advice to Management_y: Get in, get the experience and improve your resume. Then get out and onto bigger and better opportunities. Pretty much any other high sales restaurant concept will pay you more and take better care of you. But Cheesecake is a great way to prepare for the future.

It's not a place where you do $500 in sales and have a 25% tip percentage, more like $1800 in sales with a 12% tip percentage. Also, the tip out is a total of 4.5% of your sales, which is a bit higher than most places, however in that restaurant you really rely on the help of the rest of your team.
Advice to Management_x: Try to focus more on individual praise. Any time someone does something bad everyone finds out one way or another, but there is not a lot of focus on individual praise. A lot of times the positive feedback is in the form of "hey guys great shift last night" or whatever, instead of pointing people out for great individual performances.
Title_y: "Great for resume. Not for quality of life."
Pros_y: Well respected training program throughout the restaurant community. From staff member positions to managment, they will prepare you for high volume restaurants. Kitchen as well as front of house have many rules and regulations, processes and systems in place, which will out you a cut above the rest when it comes to most aspects of the restaurant industry.
Cons_y: They ask for a mile and will only reward you with an inch. they expect too much at times and rarley come through with promises. the bonus structure is not easily attainable, and even when you do hit every mark, the bonuses are not very substancial.
Advice to Management_y: Get in, get the experience and improve your resume. Then get out and onto bigger and better opportunities. Pretty much any other high sales restaurant concept will pay you more and take better care of you. But Cheesecake is a great way to prepare for the future.

Advice to Management_x: Try to focus more on individual praise. Any time someone does something bad everyone finds out one way or another, but there is not a lot of focus on individual praise. A lot of times the positive feedback is in the form of "hey guys great shift last night" or whatever, instead of pointing people out for great individual performances.

Title_y: "Great for resume. Not for quality of life."
Pros_y: Well respected training program throughout the restaurant community. From staff member positions to managment, they will prepare you for high volume restaurants. Kitchen as well as front of house have many rules and regulations, processes and systems in place, which will out you a cut above the rest when it comes to most aspects of the restaurant industry.
Cons_y: They ask for a mile and will only reward you with an inch. they expect too much at times and rarley come through with promises. the bonus structure is not easily attainable, and even when you do hit every mark, the bonuses are not very substancial.
Advice to Management_y: Get in, get the experience and improve your resume. Then get out and onto bigger and better opportunities. Pretty much any other high sales restaurant concept will pay you more and take better care of you. But Cheesecake is a great way to prepare for the future.

Pros_x: Great schedule flexibility and money compared to other restaurants around the city. The place is huge so you can usually get in our out of shifts if you need to, and it stays busy enough that you can make good consistent money (for serving tables).
Cons_x: The Cheesecake Factory unfortunately attracts some extremely undesirable clientele, especially on the weekends. You can see some really really low tip percentages, but usually those shifts come with really high sales, so at the end of the night you still make a good amount of money, but it can be really brutal at times. It's not a place where you do $500 in sales and have a 25% tip percentage, more like $1800 in sales with a 12% tip percentage. Also, the tip out is a total of 4.5% of your sales, which is a bit higher than most places, however in that restaurant you really rely on the help of the rest of your team.
Advice to Management_x: Try to focus more on individual praise. Any time someone does something bad everyone finds out one way or another, but there is not a lot of focus on individual praise. A lot of times the positive feedback is in the form of "hey guys great shift last night" or whatever, instead of pointing people out for great individual performances.

Kitchen as well as front of house have many rules and regulations, processes and systems in place, which will out you a cut above the rest when it comes to most aspects of the restaurant industry.
Cons_y: They ask for a mile and will only reward you with an inch. they expect too much at times and rarley come through with promises. the bonus structure is not easily attainable, and even when you do hit every mark, the bonuses are not very substancial.
Advice to Management_y: Get in, get the experience and improve your resume. Then get out and onto bigger and better opportunities. Pretty much any other high sales restaurant concept will pay you more and take better care of you. But Cheesecake is a great way to prepare for the future.

Pros_x: Great schedule flexibility and money compared to other restaurants around the city. The place is huge so you can usually get in our out of shifts if you need to, and it stays busy enough that you can make good consistent money (for serving tables).
Cons_x: The Cheesecake Factory unfortunately attracts some extremely undesirable clientele, especially on the weekends. You can see some really really low tip percentages, but usually those shifts come with really high sales, so at the end of the night you still make a good amount of money, but it can be really brutal at times. It's not a place where you do $500 in sales and have a 25% tip percentage, more like $1800 in sales with a 12% tip percentage. Also, the tip out is a total of 4.5% of your sales, which is a bit higher than most places, however in that restaurant you really rely on the help of the rest of your team.
Advice to Management_x: Try to focus more on individual praise. Any time someone does something bad everyone finds out one way or another, but there is not a lot of focus on individual praise. A lot of times the positive feedback is in the form of "hey guys great shift last night" or whatever, instead of pointing people out for great individual performances.

Advice to Management_y: Get in, get the experience and improve your resume. Then get out and onto bigger and better opportunities. Pretty much any other high sales restaurant concept will pay you more and take better care of you. But Cheesecake is a great way to prepare for the future.

Pros_x: Great schedule flexibility and money compared to other restaurants around the city. The place is huge so you can usually get in our out of shifts if you need to, and it stays busy enough that you can make good consistent money (for serving tables).
Cons_x: The Cheesecake Factory unfortunately attracts some extremely undesirable clientele, especially on the weekends. You can see some really really low tip percentages, but usually those shifts come with really high sales, so at the end of the night you still make a good amount of money, but it can be really brutal at times. It's not a place where you do $500 in sales and have a 25% tip percentage, more like $1800 in sales with a 12% tip percentage. Also, the tip out is a total of 4.5% of your sales, which is a bit higher than most places, however in that restaurant you really rely on the help of the rest of your team.
Advice to Management_x: Try to focus more on individual praise. Any time someone does something bad everyone finds out one way or another, but there is not a lot of focus on individual praise. A lot of times the positive feedback is in the form of "hey guys great shift last night" or whatever, instead of pointing people out for great individual performances.

Advice to Management_y: Get in, get the experience and improve your resume. Then get out and onto bigger and better opportunities. Pretty much any other high sales restaurant concept will pay you more and take better care of you. But Cheesecake is a great way to prepare for the future.

Pros_x: Great schedule flexibility and money compared to other restaurants around the city. The place is huge so you can usually get in our out of shifts if you need to, and it stays busy enough that you can make good consistent money (for serving tables).
Cons_x: The Cheesecake Factory unfortunately attracts some extremely undesirable clientele, especially on the weekends. You can see some really really low tip percentages, but usually those shifts come with really high sales, so at the end of the night you still make a good amount of money, but it can be really brutal at times. It's not a place where you do $500 in sales and have a 25% tip percentage, more like $1800 in sales with a 12% tip percentage. Also, the tip out is a total of 4.5% of your sales, which is a bit higher than most places, however in that restaurant you really rely on the help of the rest of your team.
Advice to Management_x: Try to focus more on individual praise. Any time someone does something bad everyone finds out one way or another, but there is not a lot of focus on individual praise. A lot of times the positive feedback is in the form of "hey guys great shift last night" or whatever, instead of pointing people out for great individual performances.

Advice to Management_y: Get in, get the experience and improve your resume. Then get out and onto bigger and better opportunities. Pretty much any other high sales restaurant concept will pay you more and take better care of you. But Cheesecake is a great way to prepare for the future.

Pros_x: Great schedule flexibility and money compared to other restaurants around the city. The place is huge so you can usually get in our out of shifts if you need to, and it stays busy enough that you can make good consistent money (for serving tables).
Cons_x: The Cheesecake Factory unfortunately attracts some extremely undesirable clientele, especially on the weekends. You can see some really really low tip percentages, but usually those shifts come with really high sales, so at the end of the night you still make a good amount of money, but it can be really brutal at times. It's not a place where you do $500 in sales and have a 25% tip percentage, more like $1800 in sales with a 12% tip percentage. Also, the tip out is a total of 4.5% of your sales, which is a bit higher than most places, however in that restaurant you really rely on the help of the rest of your team.
Advice to Management_x: Try to focus more on individual praise. Any time someone does something bad everyone finds out one way or another, but there is not a lot of focus on individual praise. A lot of times the positive feedback is in the form of "hey guys great shift last night" or whatever, instead of pointing people out for great individual performances.

Advice to Management_y: Get in, get the experience and improve your resume. Then get out and onto bigger and better opportunities. Pretty much any other high sales restaurant concept will pay you more and take better care of you. But Cheesecake is a great way to prepare for the future.

Pros_x: Great schedule flexibility and money compared to other restaurants around the city. The place is huge so you can usually get in our out of shifts if you need to, and it stays busy enough that you can make good consistent money (for serving tables).
Cons_x: The Cheesecake Factory unfortunately attracts some extremely undesirable clientele, especially on the weekends. You can see some really really low tip percentages, but usually those shifts come with really high sales, so at the end of the night you still make a good amount of money, but it can be really brutal at times. It's not a place where you do $500 in sales and have a 25% tip percentage, more like $1800 in sales with a 12% tip percentage. Also, the tip out is a total of 4.5% of your sales, which is a bit higher than most places, however in that restaurant you really rely on the help of the rest of your team.
Advice to Management_x: Try to focus more on individual praise. Any time someone does something bad everyone finds out one way or another, but there is not a lot of focus on individual praise. A lot of times the positive feedback is in the form of "hey guys great shift last night" or whatever, instead of pointing people out for great individual performances.

Advice to Management_y: Get in, get the experience and improve your resume. Then get out and onto bigger and better opportunities. Pretty much any other high sales restaurant concept will pay you more and take better care of you. But Cheesecake is a great way to prepare for the future.

Pros_x: Great schedule flexibility and money compared to other restaurants around the city. The place is huge so you can usually get in our out of shifts if you need to, and it stays busy enough that you can make good consistent money (for serving tables).
Cons_x: The Cheesecake Factory unfortunately attracts some extremely undesirable clientele, especially on the weekends. You can see some really really low tip percentages, but usually those shifts come with really high sales, so at the end of the night you still make a good amount of money, but it can be really brutal at times. It's not a place where you do $500 in sales and have a 25% tip percentage, more like $1800 in sales with a 12% tip percentage. Also, the tip out is a total of 4.5% of your sales, which is a bit higher than most places, however in that restaurant you really rely on the help of the rest of your team.
Advice to Management_x: Try to focus more on individual praise. Any time someone does something bad everyone finds out one way or another, but there is not a lot of focus on individual praise. A lot of times the positive feedback is in the form of "hey guys great shift last night" or whatever, instead of pointing people out for great individual performances.

Kitchen as well as front of house have many rules and regulations, processes and systems in place, which will out you a cut above the rest when it comes to most aspects of the restaurant industry.
Cons_y: They ask for a mile and will only reward you with an inch. they expect too much at times and rarley come through with promises. the bonus structure is not easily attainable, and even when you do hit every mark, the bonuses are not very substancial.
Advice to Management_y: Get in, get the experience and improve your resume. Then get out and onto bigger and better opportunities. Pretty much any other high sales restaurant concept will pay you more and take better care of you. But Cheesecake is a great way to prepare for the future.

Title_x: "Great place to work and great atmosphere"
Pros_x: Friendly staff and managers who respect your opinion.
Cons_x: Not a lot of room for growth.

Pros_x: - Good opportunities to cross-train and grow within the company.. - Company is very open to feedback from employees.. - Allows for flexible schedules.
Cons_x: - Somewhat unprofessional and "high school"-like environment, though I imagine this is not uncommon in the restaurant industry (e.g. gossiping, servers socializing in hearing range of guests, etc.)

Title_x: "A great fast paced company to be a part of with high standards"
Pros_x: Very team oriented. The managers are very helpful and driven. There are a lot of shifts to work. The money is great. If full-time there are really good health benefits offered. Flexible scheduling, and short shifts make it a great job for a full-time student. Always busy.
Cons_x: Because of the fast pace management doesn't have time to take care of staff at times. Hosts regularly seat all tables at the same time. If full-time servers are very overworked and burned out. Weekends must be worked as well as holidays. Shifts can go really late at night.
Advice to Management_x: Change the rules as far as seating a server all tables at once. This rule can really hurt the server and cause them to be overworked, as well as risk hurting the guest experience. Breaker and food-running shifts should pay better. There should be more food-runners scheduled each shift. Work life balance is a huge problem. Management doesn't care at all about work life balance.

Advice to Management_y: Get in, get the experience and improve your resume. Then get out and onto bigger and better opportunities. Pretty much any other high sales restaurant concept will pay you more and take better care of you. But Cheesecake is a great way to prepare for the future.

Pros_x: Good people to work with and better chances of moving up
Cons_x: Work too hard for little pay
Advice to Management_x: none at the moment
Title_y: "Great for resume. Not for quality of life."
Pros_y: Well respected training program throughout the restaurant community. From staff member positions to managment, they will prepare you for high volume restaurants. Kitchen as well as front of house have many rules and regulations, processes and systems in place, which will out you a cut above the rest when it comes to most aspects of the restaurant industry.
Cons_y: They ask for a mile and will only reward you with an inch. they expect too much at times and rarley come through with promises. the bonus structure is not easily attainable, and even when you do hit every mark, the bonuses are not very substancial.

Pros_x: Flexible scheduling (except for Sunday brunch, I'm forced to work these :( ). . I love the fact that I have been able to travel to other cities & enjoy my non CCF work & I enjoy being around my co-workers. I enjoy the fact that I can work 5-6 hr days & walk away w/ more than I would making an hourly wage. I enjoy the fact that I get 50% off food when scheduled & 25% when not.
Cons_x: Management does not listen to me & apparently does not communicate well amongst themselves.
Advice to Management_x: I hate the feeling that I'm just there or not respected by the majority of mgt & treated unfairly when it comes to scheduling, advancement w/i the company & favoritism. I don't have to be a favorite, but I do expect to have the same opportunities to make money as the next person & if I'm not excelling, please elaborate as to how, give examples, etc...To this day, I'm simply not sure of what exactly I'm doing wrong to the point that I don't get assigned for particular sections, I can only pickup & can't even do that all of the time, why I'm not trusted to be a DT (designated trainer), & why I'm treated as an alien or someone who does not know what they are doing. I do the best I can & would to be treated as such. I'm not perfect, but I do work very hard & want the same opportunities to prosper as the next person.

Title_x: "I love my coworkers! Management is great"
Pros_x: Management is awesome, coworkers are friendly and there is a great bond, money is fairly decent from what I have made. You can maintain a flexible schedule and work far less then 40 hours and still make great money.
Cons_x: Customers....There are a lot of foreign people who do not know how to tip. There really is no career advancement here so you get stuck in a dead end job. Also, you do have to work weekends to make money.
Advice to Management_x: Keep doing what your doing. I would only ask that you look into different uniforms since the ones we currently wear are not practical.

Pros_x: Flexible work schedule, amazing menu, rigorous training and development program, excellent opportunities for advancement and career growth.
Cons_x: Getting fat. Sometimes the guests are scamming for free meals/ drinks.
Advice to Management_x: The best part of coming to work is knowing I'm supported by a fantastic team of managers and staff. There should be a way for you to see just which managers are contributing and which ones are actually getting in the way of the mission. Over time, those managers weed themselves out, but waiting for that to happen is causing guest relations to go down in flames.

Title_x: "The Company in a whole is worth the daily grind."
Pros_x: Teamwork enviroment. Beautiful Restaurant, quality food being served.
Cons_x: When things go wrong it can create a downward spiral effect from the kitchen, bakery, bar and restaurant.
Advice to Management_x: The sign of a great manager is to motivate staff to want to do their job, and do it well. Staff alignment before each shift I believe should be inspiring and motivating not 30 lectures on how to make the manager's job easier.

Cons_x: When things go wrong it can create a downward spiral effect from the kitchen, bakery, bar and restaurant.
Advice to Management_x: The sign of a great manager is to motivate staff to want to do their job, and do it well. Staff alignment before each shift I believe should be inspiring and motivating not 30 lectures on how to make the manager's job easier.
Title_y: "Great for resume. Not for quality of life."
Pros_y: Well respected training program throughout the restaurant community. From staff member positions to managment, they will prepare you for high volume restaurants. Kitchen as well as front of house have many rules and regulations, processes and systems in place, which will out you a cut above the rest when it comes to most aspects of the restaurant industry.
Cons_y: They ask for a mile and will only reward you with an inch. they expect too much at times and rarley come through with promises. the bonus structure is not easily attainable, and even when you do hit every mark, the bonuses are not very substancial.
Advice to Management_y: Get in, get the experience and improve your resume. Then get out and onto bigger and better opportunities. Pretty much any other high sales restaurant concept will pay you more and take better care of you. But Cheesecake is a great way to prepare for the future.

Pros_x: - Relatively good food;. - Good name keeps restaurant busy;. - Excellent location;. - Excellent scheduling system
Cons_x: - Customers who get attracted by Cheesecake Brand don't tip well and you have to pay off a lot of your tips to runners/bussers, when your sales volume is high and tip % low it really feels you spent your time sweating for nothing.. - Most customers are rude and overly fussy, loads of drama queens who only want to get an item off their check.. - Managers do not care about doing even simple tasks that can lead to more customer satisfaction, they only care to look good in front of someone who is making a mistake by correcting it inappropriately.
Advice to Management_x: - Send the whole team of managers in Chicago location to the proper management school one by one and make sure they do not return unless they pass 90% including practicals.

Pros_x: I love the people I work with. The restaurants are beautifully designed and decorated. Everyone I have met who knows about The Cheesecake Factory tell me that they "love that place".
Cons_x: The frantic pace of business at times seems overwhelming to most of the employees.
Advice to Management_x: Cutting labor also means that many guests will not recieve the best service. Skeleton crews may save money, but will not insure total guest satisfaction.

Title_x: "Best large restaurant company to work as a server."
Pros_x: Strong training program that really spends the time to help new servers learn the menu and the standards of service. Expectations for standards are well-defined, including language to use and steps of service. The company also creates a strong sense of community with company-wide communications, volunteer programs and opportunities to transfer or change position. The company is well-organized, has quality products, maintains strong marketing, and continues to grow.
Cons_x: I wish the benefits package for hourly staff was better, but those are losing ground in many companies, and that's all in a state of change, anyway.

Cons_y: They ask for a mile and will only reward you with an inch. they expect too much at times and rarley come through with promises. the bonus structure is not easily attainable, and even when you do hit every mark, the bonuses are not very substancial.
Advice to Management_y: Get in, get the experience and improve your resume. Then get out and onto bigger and better opportunities. Pretty much any other high sales restaurant concept will pay you more and take better care of you. But Cheesecake is a great way to prepare for the future.

Pros_x: This is one of the best jobs you can have waiting tables. On average I make $20 per hour. For me they have been flexible with my schedule and it has been a great job to have while I am putting myself through college.
Cons_x: When your store has changed general managers 3 times in the last 3 years you know that something is up. In my opinion all of the managers have had excellent qualities. I believe that this is just the nature of the corporate world.
Advice to Management_x: Listen to what your employees are saying and if you treat them with respect and show them consideration they will do the same for you.
Title_y: "Great for resume. Not for quality of life."

Kitchen as well as front of house have many rules and regulations, processes and systems in place, which will out you a cut above the rest when it comes to most aspects of the restaurant industry.

Title_x: "Very busy,pays the bills but that's all really"
Pros_x: The training is very thorough and emphasis is on quality and guest relations. In my particular store, the kitchen is very smooth and fast. Friendships can be developed with fellow staff that can become long lasting. The GM at my location is amazing and his good morale does flow downward when he's there.
Cons_x: Management favoritism is a big problem with my location as well as the others from what I've read. It seems that no matter how hard you work toward the "Cheesecake Mission" or how little you contribute, it doesn't make a difference. If you are on a mgr's good list and kiss a lot butt, you can pretty much get anything you want, and by all means don't make any waves - you'll end up a second rate number. The worst thing they did to us was take away our smoking privileges! The CCF became a multi-billion dollar company after 30 years with servers who smoked and when you walk by a fine dining restaurant and see that their employees can go out for a smoke and we can't it kinda makes you mad. After a busy 4 hours waiting on rude foreigners, a smoke would certainly be nice for the ones who have the habbit- instead you get a progressively more irritated server! Speaking of foreiners,, there is NO policy against auto-grats and we should be allowed to do it at locations that suffer the low or no tips from Europeans, Canadians and others who just don't wanna tip.....The company as a whole is aware of the problem yet refuses to do anything about it , to me that demonstrates they only care about their bank accounts and as long as the check total is paid.......One more thing......why for such a HUGE company am I having to pay $100 or more a month for health insurance ?
Advice to Management_x: Stop the favoritism!! We are not in 4th grade folks!! If we were I'd be sure to bring an apple to work with me sometimes. Give back our smoking priviledges!!! If you are a smoker, it relieves stress when u have one in stressful situations. If you are not allowed, the stress only builds. If you're not a smoker then stop trying to regulate my rights as a smoker in not in California for Pete sake! I'm a big girl I can figure out a good time to slip one in without hurting anybody- we've done it for years that way. Don't forget us career servers when you're rolling out sections, just because I'm not one of your pets or not as cute and pretty as someone else, I've put in a LOT of my life to this company and would LOVE some real appreciation for it---- otherwise , what's the point? Right?

Advice to Management_y: Get in, get the experience and improve your resume. Then get out and onto bigger and better opportunities. Pretty much any other high sales restaurant concept will pay you more and take better care of you. But Cheesecake is a great way to prepare for the future.

Pros_x: Consistant money, great training,and fun work environment.
Cons_x: Little advancement opportunity, management can be difficult.
Title_y: "Great for resume. Not for quality of life."
Pros_y: Well respected training program throughout the restaurant community. From staff member positions to managment, they will prepare you for high volume restaurants. Kitchen as well as front of house have many rules and regulations, processes and systems in place, which will out you a cut above the rest when it comes to most aspects of the restaurant industry.
Cons_y: They ask for a mile and will only reward you with an inch. they expect too much at times and rarley come through with promises. the bonus structure is not easily attainable, and even when you do hit every mark, the bonuses are not very substancial.
Advice to Management_y: Get in, get the experience and improve your resume. Then get out and onto bigger and better opportunities. Pretty much any other high sales restaurant concept will pay you more and take better care of you. But Cheesecake is a great way to prepare for the future.

Pros_x: As with all serving jobs, flexible scheduling is always a plus. Also, there are food runners and, in some locations, people who take care of the cleaning and marrying of ketchups, for example--all of which reduce your responsibilities as a server, diminishing your side work etc. The shifts are relatively smooth, even on busy nights, which is nice. I've worked at other restaurants where you run out of everything when its busy and your life sucks. But Cheesecake runs pretty well. You have what you need for the most part.. Also, its pretty easy to move between stores which is really convenient and helped me get through college.
Cons_x: Obviously the uniforms are horrible. Whoever thought of all white in a restaurant environment needs help. I understand them wanting to present as clean of an appearance to guests as possible, but come on! You learn to dodge stains and stay clean in a weird way, but some things just can't be avoided--like the dirtying of the bottom hem of your pants. However, the uniforms and ankle-length aprons are extremely uncomfortable...they retain the heat and sweat and it's gross.. . There is also little to NO employee appreciation with the exception of a holiday cheesecake. However, this cheesecake is sold by Costco so is not the same caliber the restaurant offers guests. Cheesecake Factory would NEVER even think about selling the cheesecake it gives to its employees in the store. Also, there are never any contests or challenges that make work fun. You can get the "power tie" which gives you free meals based upon customer satisfaction ratings, however, the menu from which you get to chose your meals is severely limited--mainly to appetizers and the less enjoyable/cheaper food items.
Advice to Management_x: Employee appreciation and elevating morale should be your highest concerns. And trying to "hype" up the staff using just words during your alignment meetings isn't enough....

Pros_x: Fast paced so this is a great place to work if you get bored easily and like stimulation. Fun environment most of the time. Great pay in comparison to most other restaurants.
Cons_x: Can be stressful, customers can be needy or really difficult, but that is all with most restaurants. Your experience will also greatly vary based on the managers you are working closely with.

Pros_x: Flexible schedule, they are great about requests and hot schedules makes it easy to pick up shifts, and there are always people that don't want to work.. Friendly staff
Cons_x: Keeping the uniform white gets expensive and time consuming. . Favoritism- enough said. . Long shifts... we're talking over 10 hour shifts on the weekends without a break (YES, it's illegal and it is standard practice, I promise the money most of the times is not worth it). . This company DOES NOT CARE ABOUT YOU. They recently changed their seating to policy to 'preferred seating 1st' meaning the booths get sat first, so if you have a section that is all table (by the way sections are never bigger than 4 tables) your only hope of getting sat is if every booth is full, also the bar seating has been taking out of the rotation all together. A few people will make all the money the rest will be stuck with a few tables all night.. . You will have a food run shift and/or a stand by shift every week, meaning you will have a shift you may or may not be used on and/or a shift where you are just running food and making very little every week.. . At my location the clientele were not likely to tip, so if you were not able to add grat for a party you would get 10% if you were lucky and very good, which is problematic when you are tipping out 4% of sales every night.
Advice to Management_x: TAKE CARE OF YOUR STAFF! With the new seating policy you need to make sure everyone is set up to make money so they can eat, move the sections, and move the staff around to make it fair. If for no other reason than to keep your turn over rate low as training a new employee is expensive. I was praised often for my professionalism and how well I treated our guests, I did everything I was asked, and in return because I wasn't among the group of favorites I knew that I could count on bad sections, in spite of praise. You lost a great employee, I know I'm great, my management team told me all the time, I've been in the industry a decade and I was picked up the day after I dropped a resume at an other restaurant. I couldn't wait to get out and am much better off for it.

Pros_x: decent starting pay and pretty nice co-workers
Cons_x: The management is insane and forgetful, schedual comes out weird and many times screwed over when it comes to hours and the GM over micro manages. been waiting over a month to switch to a different section of the restauraunt but still no word and still have not had my 6 month review even though i have been there over 7 months. many things end up taking long when it is through management.
Advice to Management_x: need to start listening to the employees more

Pros_x: With just about any restaurant you can pick your own schedule, to some extent. I love that they have hotschedules to handle all our schedule needs.
Cons_x: Bartenders only make min. wage, and do way to much work for the pay!!
Advice to Management_x: Increase your bartenders pay, they deserve it!

Cons_y: They ask for a mile and will only reward you with an inch. they expect too much at times and rarley come through with promises. the bonus structure is not easily attainable, and even when you do hit every mark, the bonuses are not very substancial.
Advice to Management_y: Get in, get the experience and improve your resume. Then get out and onto bigger and better opportunities. Pretty much any other high sales restaurant concept will pay you more and take better care of you. But Cheesecake is a great way to prepare for the future.

Pros_x: With just about any restaurant you can pick your own schedule, to some extent. I love that they have hotschedules to handle all our schedule needs.
Cons_x: Bartenders only make min. wage, and do way to much work for the pay!!
Advice to Management_x: Increase your bartenders pay, they deserve it!

Pros_x: i liked most of the people i worked with. the restaurant was beautiful inside. i liked a lot of the food. i learned a lot about people, the good and the bad.
Cons_x: most of the customers that dine there are beyond cheap. they want fine dining 5 star service and want to tip on a denny's bill. i have worked in restaurants for over 15 years and have never disliked a job so much. customers would be completely rude and out of line and the management doesnt care, well not about their employees. the managers never back up their employees at all.
Advice to Management_x: your employees work hard to get a job there. a customer treating your staff horribly should not be accepted. back up your employees more

Pros_x: Flexibility is always what a person is looking for when working as a server. The cheesecake factory affords it's servers the time and flexibility to work while going to school.
Cons_x: As is the case with many corporate restaurants, management is almost always a pain. Give someone a taste of authority and, more often than not, they will abuse it.

Pros_x: Tips were above average on Friday's and Saturdays; however, you had to be on the manager's good side to be scheduled for those days. The other servers were genuine, nice, and helpful people. If you needed a day off for whatever reason, it was easy to find a coworker willing to take the shift for you. The chef's are excellent and execute delicious food.
Cons_x: Being a male, the manager's (all men) were more drawn to women servers for obvious reasons and flirted with them non-stop. Because of their infatuation with the younger women servers, all the best sections and times to serve were scheduled for the women--leaving the men to the worst sections. Favoritism was also unprofessional with respect to how the manager's treated pretty women employee's in comparison to how they treated the others.
Advice to Management_x: Respect your servers, don't talk down to them, keep your tempers under control. Also keep in mind that some of us are going to school and when we tell you a month in advance that we have a final exam on a certain date, don't tell us 2 days before we must come to work or were fired.

Pros_y: Well respected training program throughout the restaurant community. From staff member positions to managment, they will prepare you for high volume restaurants. Kitchen as well as front of house have many rules and regulations, processes and systems in place, which will out you a cut above the rest when it comes to most aspects of the restaurant industry.
Cons_y: They ask for a mile and will only reward you with an inch. they expect too much at times and rarley come through with promises. the bonus structure is not easily attainable, and even when you do hit every mark, the bonuses are not very substancial.

Pros_x: Tips were above average on Friday's and Saturdays; however, you had to be on the manager's good side to be scheduled for those days. The other servers were genuine, nice, and helpful people. If you needed a day off for whatever reason, it was easy to find a coworker willing to take the shift for you. The chef's are excellent and execute delicious food.
Cons_x: Being a male, the manager's (all men) were more drawn to women servers for obvious reasons and flirted with them non-stop. Because of their infatuation with the younger women servers, all the best sections and times to serve were scheduled for the women--leaving the men to the worst sections. Favoritism was also unprofessional with respect to how the manager's treated pretty women employee's in comparison to how they treated the others.
Advice to Management_x: Respect your servers, don't talk down to them, keep your tempers under control. Also keep in mind that some of us are going to school and when we tell you a month in advance that we have a final exam on a certain date, don't tell us 2 days before we must come to work or were fired.

Title_x: "Decent job for college student, but difficult to have normal life within the constraints of the hours."
Pros_x: Great reputation, good insurance benefits, potential for transferring and movement within company locations.
Cons_x: The typical grind of food service, values are great but inconsistently put together and enforced.
Advice to Management_x: Valuing your employees seems to be a priority of the company, but it is not clearly filtered down through lower level management.

Pros_x: Co-workers are AMAZING, the food is really good, sampling the new food before it hits the menu is always a plus, they work around your schedule.
Cons_x: the management isnt always the best, the hours can be tough[getting out on time is RARE], dealing with corporate can be just as stressful
Advice to Management_x: get it together guys...get it together. all of the employees are like a little family but management can be...less then desirable thats for sure. when you walk into work asking when the GM goes home thats a bad sign

Cons_y: They ask for a mile and will only reward you with an inch. they expect too much at times and rarley come through with promises. the bonus structure is not easily attainable, and even when you do hit every mark, the bonuses are not very substancial.
Advice to Management_y: Get in, get the experience and improve your resume. Then get out and onto bigger and better opportunities. Pretty much any other high sales restaurant concept will pay you more and take better care of you. But Cheesecake is a great way to prepare for the future.

Pros_x: Co-workers are AMAZING, the food is really good, sampling the new food before it hits the menu is always a plus, they work around your schedule.
Cons_x: the management isnt always the best, the hours can be tough[getting out on time is RARE], dealing with corporate can be just as stressful
Advice to Management_x: get it together guys...get it together. all of the employees are like a little family but management can be...less then desirable thats for sure. when you walk into work asking when the GM goes home thats a bad sign

Title_x: "Good management team and environment but not that focused on employee needs"
Pros_x: Provided with very good training and the hours were plenty. Fast paced environment. Good system to swap shifts with other coworkers.
Cons_x: As a hostess, we were sometimes forced to work 12+ hour shifts on weekends...with no breaks. This was very tiring when you haven't eaten all day, are running around constantly, and ask for a break and get denied. The managers all have different techniques for seating guests and got upset if you didn't use their ways. When certain employees don't do their jobs, nothing is done.
Advice to Management_x: Care more about your employees and maybe they won't leave.

Pros_x: Great food, great people, great atmosphere. People care about the guest, the staff, the food and the beautiful restaurant. Fun place to work and be proud of! We like to say our staff and managers are ". . . so Cheesecake" as a way to say they are so wonderful.
Cons_x: It's a busy place with a huge menu. So time goes by fast but there is much to do. Having lots of hands and help from others to learn so much is what makes it viable.
Advice to Management_x: Continue doing what you do to support the amazing staff.
Title_y: "Real Hard Place to Work, Never Again"
Pros_y: They pay a decent wage
Cons_y: Taught to rule by do it or else, and are ruled by the same standards
Advice to Management_y: Learn People skills

Title_x: "It all evens out as a server."
Pros_x: When this establishment is busy, you can do extremely well; but when it is not, obviously it shifts in the other direction. The guests go both ways as well, but more often than not, you have great people dining here.
Cons_x: You don't get free food. You aren't provided breaks. And, depending on management, you can be stuck in a shift and unable to go home when it's not busy.
Title_y: "Real Hard Place to Work, Never Again"
Pros_y: They pay a decent wage
Cons_y: Taught to rule by do it or else, and are ruled by the same standards
Advice to Management_y: Learn People skills

Title_x: "It all evens out as a server."
Pros_x: When this establishment is busy, you can do extremely well; but when it is not, obviously it shifts in the other direction. The guests go both ways as well, but more often than not, you have great people dining here.
Cons_x: You don't get free food. You aren't provided breaks. And, depending on management, you can be stuck in a shift and unable to go home when it's not busy.

Pros_x: I had started as a server and moved quickly to a management role. The managers saw the potential in me and became great mentors and invested their time in my development. The training is fantastic at every level. The company is VERY focused on the details. Being great isn't good enough- they strive for perfection.
Cons_x: I don't think you could be successful if you weren't 100% dedicated to the company and the mission. It takes hard work and dedication, and if you don't have the buy-in it would probably be intolerable.
Advice to Management_x: Don't compromise on what you do or strive to do.

Pros_x: CCF waiters make above average in tips due to the high prices of the food and large sections.
Cons_x: The all-white uniforms are very tough to keep clean.
Pros_y: I had started as a server and moved quickly to a management role. The managers saw the potential in me and became great mentors and invested their time in my development. The training is fantastic at every level. The company is VERY focused on the details. Being great isn't good enough- they strive for perfection.
Cons_y: I don't think you could be successful if you weren't 100% dedicated to the company and the mission. It takes hard work and dedication, and if you don't have the buy-in it would probably be intolerable.
Advice to Management_y: Don't compromise on what you do or strive to do.

Pros_x: During Summer you get a lot of hours but it all depends how willing you are to work. You can get up to 12 hours a day but you cant complain if you can not get off a schedule like that. Usually if you start off that shift in the morning you will end up leaving at around 3 o'clock rush hour or til 5, if you come in around afternoon you get to leave around 7 or even up to midnight. if you come in at around 5 pm you get to leave around 1 am or even 3am all depending your job. During slow season you may be sent home after about 4 or 5 hours of work. There are some people who understand the stress and can cooperate by being a part of the solution, then there are those who become a part of the problem.
Cons_x: If you didn't get sent home early during the slow season you are being left alone to do the job of two people which can be stressful and happens quite often, so you are more or less lucky if you didn't get stuck by yourself. They start you off with a decent pay but you will rarely see any increase unless you can really impress somebody. During peak periods you will have managers who expect for you to go "above and beyond your work of line" but can also backfire if you fall behind on your main task and then you give everyone a reason to blame you. A lot of times the company would have new items on the menu and requires the company to order new ingredients everyday but if the item is not available, you cant sell the item and becomes an issue with everybody until it gets resolved which can last of up to an hour at times. A lot of the Expo are unreasonable at times and like to yell instead of being of some help.
Advice to Management_x: Really practice what you are teaching and not just tell the employees to follow rules because the rule book says so. I was happy to hear the company does things by the book and upset to realize that is a lie. You cant expect the employees to go by the book if they see some one with experience do something the book is against.
Pros_y: I had started as a server and moved quickly to a management role. The managers saw the potential in me and became great mentors and invested their time in my development. The training is fantastic at every level. The company is VERY focused on the details. Being great isn't good enough- they strive for perfection.
Cons_y: I don't think you could be successful if you weren't 100% dedicated to the company and the mission. It takes hard work and dedication, and if you don't have the buy-in it would probably be intolerable.
Advice to Management_y: Don't compromise on what you do or strive to do.

Pros_x: During Summer you get a lot of hours but it all depends how willing you are to work. You can get up to 12 hours a day but you cant complain if you can not get off a schedule like that. Usually if you start off that shift in the morning you will end up leaving at around 3 o'clock rush hour or til 5, if you come in around afternoon you get to leave around 7 or even up to midnight. if you come in at around 5 pm you get to leave around 1 am or even 3am all depending your job. During slow season you may be sent home after about 4 or 5 hours of work. There are some people who understand the stress and can cooperate by being a part of the solution, then there are those who become a part of the problem.
Cons_x: If you didn't get sent home early during the slow season you are being left alone to do the job of two people which can be stressful and happens quite often, so you are more or less lucky if you didn't get stuck by yourself. They start you off with a decent pay but you will rarely see any increase unless you can really impress somebody. During peak periods you will have managers who expect for you to go "above and beyond your work of line" but can also backfire if you fall behind on your main task and then you give everyone a reason to blame you. A lot of times the company would have new items on the menu and requires the company to order new ingredients everyday but if the item is not available, you cant sell the item and becomes an issue with everybody until it gets resolved which can last of up to an hour at times. A lot of the Expo are unreasonable at times and like to yell instead of being of some help.
Advice to Management_x: Really practice what you are teaching and not just tell the employees to follow rules because the rule book says so. I was happy to hear the company does things by the book and upset to realize that is a lie. You cant expect the employees to go by the book if they see some one with experience do something the book is against.

Cons_y: I don't think you could be successful if you weren't 100% dedicated to the company and the mission. It takes hard work and dedication, and if you don't have the buy-in it would probably be intolerable.

Cons_x: rarely able to take scheduled break, managers do not help scheduling especially with commuting workers, a lot of favoritism
Advice to Management_x: take into account those who would be willing to travel to work but depend on public transportation. You can't schedule us to close every sunday night when the last bus is at 9:15. There should be random stop ins by upper management to evaluate current messy and rude managers at a slow business location.
Pros_y: I had started as a server and moved quickly to a management role. The managers saw the potential in me and became great mentors and invested their time in my development. The training is fantastic at every level. The company is VERY focused on the details. Being great isn't good enough- they strive for perfection.
Cons_y: I don't think you could be successful if you weren't 100% dedicated to the company and the mission. It takes hard work and dedication, and if you don't have the buy-in it would probably be intolerable.
Advice to Management_y: Don't compromise on what you do or strive to do.

Pros_x: Very professional in the business aspect of things. Everything was very structured and corporate.

Pros_x: I am so glad I got hired here! All of the employees are so kind and helpful, they'll give new people tips on how to do well and get a rhythm of how the restaurant works. Management works with you and basically treat you like an equal to them. I really like the fact that they give you a week long in-class training course, because it sure helps you out when you actually get on the floor and start working!
Cons_x: Well, the restaurant is HUGE, so it takes some time to learn where every item you'll need for side-work is. And when you start off you get pretty small sections, so you won't be making good money at first. Oh yeah, and they also ask you to sign away your breaks, it's optional but encouraged.
Pros_y: good pay, fun and exciting work enviroment
Cons_y: everything else, no work/life blanace

Title_x: "You're only as good as your worst hostess."
Pros_x: Each day was fun and exciting. Even as a host, I became very close to the servers. The environment is pretty laid back as long as you maintain a professional appearance. The managers were always very nice and understanding of your needs. They really took time to get to know each employee as an individual. The pay is good for the amount of work that is expected and you don't have to bus tables which is always a plus.
Cons_x: As my title states, you are only as good as your worst hostess. If the good hostesses were working, the front desk was like a well-oiled machine. We were fast, efficient, and organized so everyone had a good time and enjoyed their shift. Unfortunately, as with every job, there were a few hostesses who fell below the expectations. These hostesses made the entire shift stressful for everyone because they were sloppy and made many mistakes so the good hostesses were having to pick up the slack.
Pros_y: Great company. Corporate culture that is well established and effective. Development that is specific and self guided and advancement that is clearly laid out and attainable.
Cons_y: You will never work harder as a manager any where else. The level of commitment and effort required to be successful is intense but you do see a reward for hard work
Advice to Management_y: Pay internal highers more

Title_x: "Very Corporate, number driven, money making, fast paced"
Pros_x: The people I worked with were great. There is plenty of money to be made there. Fast paced environment, which helps you keep busy and makes the time go by faster. I would definitely recommend working there, but just expect a corporate atmosphere. It was not for me but I don't regret working there. The overall staff including management was friendly. You can make your schedule requests on their online system. There are great health care benefits.
Cons_x: The company is driven by numbers. The culture does not have much of a family environment, you come in there to make money and you leave. It was very cliquey and management was very cut throat. I came in 2 minutes late and shift was "Shark" taken by someone that was already there waiting to pick up a shift. No flexibility to suggest any improvements for the restaurant because everything is already implemented as a system. Have to wear all white...which gets dirty real quick.
Advice to Management_x: I would advice management to get more personal with the employees and understand that they are human and not cattle. Make more activities for employees in order for them to effort to be as a whole/ team.
Pros_y: Great company. Corporate culture that is well established and effective. Development that is specific and self guided and advancement that is clearly laid out and attainable.
Cons_y: You will never work harder as a manager any where else. The level of commitment and effort required to be successful is intense but you do see a reward for hard work
Advice to Management_y: Pay internal highers more

Title_x: "Steady money and flexible schedule but very stressful!!!"
Pros_x: Flexible schedule which is a huge reason I stayed there for as long as I did,aside from that it's very structured which works well for some people and since it's usually very busy you make steady money due to the amount of tables you have over a full shift but some locations like the one I worked at have huge tourist and foreigner clientele meaning you might have 16 tables in a shift with 4 leaving you 18% or more,8 tables leaving you a normal 15% and 4 tables leaving you 10% or less or possibly totally stiffing you,you just hope it's the $25 check stiffing you and not the $150 check.Many days you go home with 10% of your sales or sometimes way less after tipping out other staff members,I've seen servers go home with $25 on $500 in sales.Sidework is not bad at all.
Cons_x: Serving at a location with so many foreigners and tourists you have to have very thick skin and put the many bad tips behind you or you might freak out with your next table,serving there is not a job many people can handle.I saw many servers look like they wanted to punch someone after getting $3 on a $97 check and then somehow have to be pleasant with the next table knowing that that tip had nothing to do with their service as the majority of servers there do a very good job,but know they have to suffer because a table comes from a country where tipping is not customary and if you dare tell them anything you risk being fired.
Advice to Management_x: I think most of the management does a pretty good job but corporate should consider having automatic gratuity on locations with a lot of international clientele,it would probably lessen the huge turnover,they literally had to hire like 12-15 servers a month to just keep the number of servers needed.
Pros_y: Great company. Corporate culture that is well established and effective. Development that is specific and self guided and advancement that is clearly laid out and attainable.
Cons_y: You will never work harder as a manager any where else. The level of commitment and effort required to be successful is intense but you do see a reward for hard work
Advice to Management_y: Pay internal highers more

Cons_y: You will never work harder as a manager any where else. The level of commitment and effort required to be successful is intense but you do see a reward for hard work
Advice to Management_y: Pay internal highers more

Title_x: "Steady money and flexible schedule but very stressful!!!"
Pros_x: Flexible schedule which is a huge reason I stayed there for as long as I did,aside from that it's very structured which works well for some people and since it's usually very busy you make steady money due to the amount of tables you have over a full shift but some locations like the one I worked at have huge tourist and foreigner clientele meaning you might have 16 tables in a shift with 4 leaving you 18% or more,8 tables leaving you a normal 15% and 4 tables leaving you 10% or less or possibly totally stiffing you,you just hope it's the $25 check stiffing you and not the $150 check.Many days you go home with 10% of your sales or sometimes way less after tipping out other staff members,I've seen servers go home with $25 on $500 in sales.Sidework is not bad at all.
Cons_x: Serving at a location with so many foreigners and tourists you have to have very thick skin and put the many bad tips behind you or you might freak out with your next table,serving there is not a job many people can handle.I saw many servers look like they wanted to punch someone after getting $3 on a $97 check and then somehow have to be pleasant with the next table knowing that that tip had nothing to do with their service as the majority of servers there do a very good job,but know they have to suffer because a table comes from a country where tipping is not customary and if you dare tell them anything you risk being fired.
Advice to Management_x: I think most of the management does a pretty good job but corporate should consider having automatic gratuity on locations with a lot of international clientele,it would probably lessen the huge turnover,they literally had to hire like 12-15 servers a month to just keep the number of servers needed.
Pros_y: Great company. Corporate culture that is well established and effective. Development that is specific and self guided and advancement that is clearly laid out and attainable.
Cons_y: You will never work harder as a manager any where else. The level of commitment and effort required to be successful is intense but you do see a reward for hard work
Advice to Management_y: Pay internal highers more

Title_x: "Neither good nor bad.....if your young and driven, you can get far..."
Pros_x: Salaries are good. Benefits are comparable to the rest of the industry. Very forgiving. BMW when you come to the GM level....Nice, if it's what you want.
Cons_x: The hours are long sometimes. They love to "dangle the carrot". Stock options have changed, not as good as it was before.
Advice to Management_x: Make sure your Managers know you care about their development. Sometimes brutal honestly is better than no feedback. Make the BMW an option.....car or better salary.

Title_x: "Depends on your location; can be a very enjoyable company to work for or a very frustrating, corporate atmosphere."
Pros_x: Professionalism, benefits, brand strength, schedule flexibility, industry training standards very high
Cons_x: Frequently too corporate-for-corporate's sake, but this depends on your location. Have had some phenomenal managers in the past as well as some managers that had no business managing anything or anyone.
Advice to Management_x: Words without actions are worse than no words at all.

Advice to Management_x: Thanks for your hard work!

Pros_x: -fast paced environment where there's always something to do (on nights and weekends). -great food, you can sometimes get a slip for a free meal. -the managers are attentive & make time to talk to you. -online scheduling is easy to use & makes it simple to switch shifts. -dress code is simple to follow
Cons_x: -during the day, especially during the week, it is very slow & boring. -a lot of people that work there are unprofessional, some I suspect are on drugs, while others are perverts. -"customer is always right" mentality - is difficult to maintain especially when customers are clearly wrong. -you have to keep track of how much you should be expecting in your paycheck because there are often discrepancies. -if you get there early you have to wait until the exact time you are supposed to be there to clock in
Advice to Management_x: give people raises more often!
Pros_y: Focused on taking care of the guest, quality of operations and product.
Cons_y: Can still be to top down controlling. Allow more autonomy at the restaurant level to drive sales and connect to the local market.

Pros_x: -fast paced environment where there's always something to do (on nights and weekends). -great food, you can sometimes get a slip for a free meal. -the managers are attentive & make time to talk to you. -online scheduling is easy to use & makes it simple to switch shifts. -dress code is simple to follow
Cons_x: -during the day, especially during the week, it is very slow & boring. -a lot of people that work there are unprofessional, some I suspect are on drugs, while others are perverts. -"customer is always right" mentality - is difficult to maintain especially when customers are clearly wrong. -you have to keep track of how much you should be expecting in your paycheck because there are often discrepancies. -if you get there early you have to wait until the exact time you are supposed to be there to clock in
Advice to Management_x: give people raises more often!
Pros_y: Focused on taking care of the guest, quality of operations and product.
Cons_y: Can still be to top down controlling. Allow more autonomy at the restaurant level to drive sales and connect to the local market.

Title_x: "A restaurant job, with a slight twist"
Pros_x: -possibility of moving up relatively fast. -after becoming a DT (trainer), when they open up new locations you can ask your GM about going to help open the store (some are even overseas). -if it's a busy location, you'll make great tips. -you can transfer to any location (after working 6 months)! this part I loved.. -
Cons_x: -if it's not busy, you make $30-50 a shift.. -customer service jobs are always hard. people complaining about things you probably had 0 control over. -managers are a hit-or-miss (my GM was FANTASTIC). -your peers will always be complaining, and in turn you will start complaining. "this ass**** left me 10% " or "this one guest is so needy". it'll happen. it's always going to happen. move on.
Pros_y: Focused on taking care of the guest, quality of operations and product.
Cons_y: Can still be to top down controlling. Allow more autonomy at the restaurant level to drive sales and connect to the local market.

Title_x: "I have enjoyed working for the company but feel they could do better."
Pros_x: Ability to advance is high. There are many different job paths depending on what you want to do. Training is given to help you succeed.
Cons_x: They take advantage of those wishing to advance and do not pay accordingly unless you push for it. The guests that come in can be less than desirable due to being attatched to malls.
Advice to Management_x: Management needs to make people their greatest resources by empowering them and paying them accordingly. A server usually makes about $15-$20/hr. When doing training, the trainer is only paid $10/hr if they are lucky and so they make less money for being a leader.

Cons_x: As a hostess I was paid minimum wage and wasn't there long enough to move up.
Advice to Management_x: Good Job.

Title_x: "Never before have I worked for such an inept and inconsiderate management staff."
Pros_x: Not many, There's air conditioning. On occasion, if it's busy enough you can actually make ok money however, there is no consistency whatsoever.
Cons_x: Many, $2.83 per hour w/no chance of a raise. A guarantee that no matter what it is management doesn't care about your problem.
Advice to Management_x: Avarice is the plight of mankind. The lack of any consistency from the kitchen is a joke. Pay your employees an appropriate wage and treat them w/respect.

Pros_x: Good workers are taken care of. Long hours but usually there was money to be made if you didn't mind working. As far as restaurant jobs go, Cheesecake Factory is one of the better ones out there. Benefits are offered and the company is growing so there is room to move up in the company if that is your goal. For many people who are just there as a temporary landing spot while they figure out what they want to do, it's a good place to work where you can make good money in an entry level job.
Cons_x: Corporate Culture sometimes limiting. Sometimes long hours expected of staff

Title_x: "Hostess is also greeter, maintenance man, lost and found, busser, security, and janitor."
Pros_x: You get a 50% off meal but employee meal discount is invalid for most dishes. You can use your 50% for some cheap chicken littles or some cheaper worthless dishes like salad. No steak, no no no..
Cons_x: You are the busier, janitor, highchair carrier, stroller parker, etc.. . You work long hours and have to clean the bathroom and refill all the napkins.. . Also, no tips at all. You walk around all day to look for open tables. You are never at standstill unless you are the greeter which is not likely if you haven't worked long enough...like 5+ year.
Pros_y: Focused on taking care of the guest, quality of operations and product.
Cons_y: Can still be to top down controlling. Allow more autonomy at the restaurant level to drive sales and connect to the local market.

Pros_x: Management and staff focus on teamwork and making employees feel united. Out of all of the restaurants I have worked in, this one is the one that is most focused on the satisfaction of guests AND employees. Also, it is ALWAYS busy there...so the money is not too bad, either.
Cons_x: Like any restaurant, being a food server can be daunting. Also, with a high staff turnover rate, staff usually works upwards of 40 hours every week...often twelve hour shifts on both saturdays and sundays. Again, the money is usually good, but often it is hard to balance work and family life working at the Cheesecake Factory.
Advice to Management_x: Keep focusing on teamwork...and bring back the chocolate coconut cream cheesecake ;)

Pros_x: Vibrant atmosphere, consistently good food & beverage products. The sheer monetary volume that the establishment is able to generate dictates that hourly employees (at least the tipped ones) can make a fairly good living and tend to stay around.
Cons_x: Below industry standards regarding time off and 401k matching program, salary is capped once you reach a certain point, 55+ hr work weeks and 10-12 hr work days are the norm, high turnover rate for managers
Advice to Management_x: Pay managers what they're worth. Try to incorporate some level of work/life balance into your management program.

Title_x: "good, easy money with hands on management"
Pros_x: I moved up from host, to food run, to server in a matter of a year and a half. Management always willing to work with you in sticky situations with guests. Good vibes between co workers and management. Fun events like dances/baseball games
Cons_x: Benefits only for persons working 25+ a week (if you do qualify it's pretty awesome from what I have heard.
Advice to Management_x: My GM, Max Escuder, is amazing. He is always looking to improve our restaurant and throw events for his employees. I truly feel like he cares and that makes all the difference. Thanks Max!

Pros_x: The work place is all ways clean and most part management is great. They promote from the inside. If you work hard and show a drive you can move up.
Cons_x: They hire lots of young people with bad work ethics and it does make your job harder cause you are working for tips.
Advice to Management_x: Stop letting the young employees do what they like with no consequence. If they are a bad worker FIRE them.
Pros_y: Good starting salary in-comparison to other companies.. Well designed training program
Cons_y: -Company policy requires only Chefs to work a scheduled 11 hours each shift. -With work demand your not given a scheduled opportunity to take a break at any point. -Typically work 4 of 5 days of a given work-week from 3pm-2am. -Will be relegated to consistently having to attend to scheduled monthly training workshops at 8am after leaving from the night before at 2am. -Provided almost no financial raise for attaining a higher management position. -Executive Chef is given little incentive to promote a manager which ultimately leads to aspiring chefs being drawn out for several months. -
Advice to Management_y: Do not apply

Cons_y: -Company policy requires only Chefs to work a scheduled 11 hours each shift. -With work demand your not given a scheduled opportunity to take a break at any point. -Typically work 4 of 5 days of a given work-week from 3pm-2am. -Will be relegated to consistently having to attend to scheduled monthly training workshops at 8am after leaving from the night before at 2am. -Provided almost no financial raise for attaining a higher management position. -Executive Chef is given little incentive to promote a manager which ultimately leads to aspiring chefs being drawn out for several months. -

Pros_x: They work with your school schedule, other job, and any personal days. Friendly staff and nice atmosphere. Employee discounts and decent opportunities to grow.
Cons_x: It feels too corporate sometimes, can be stuck working long hours, too many employees and things go unnoticed.

Cons_y: -Company policy requires only Chefs to work a scheduled 11 hours each shift. -With work demand your not given a scheduled opportunity to take a break at any point. -Typically work 4 of 5 days of a given work-week from 3pm-2am. -Will be relegated to consistently having to attend to scheduled monthly training workshops at 8am after leaving from the night before at 2am. -Provided almost no financial raise for attaining a higher management position. -Executive Chef is given little incentive to promote a manager which ultimately leads to aspiring chefs being drawn out for several months. -

Cons_y: -Company policy requires only Chefs to work a scheduled 11 hours each shift. -With work demand your not given a scheduled opportunity to take a break at any point. -Typically work 4 of 5 days of a given work-week from 3pm-2am. -Will be relegated to consistently having to attend to scheduled monthly training workshops at 8am after leaving from the night before at 2am. -Provided almost no financial raise for attaining a higher management position. -Executive Chef is given little incentive to promote a manager which ultimately leads to aspiring chefs being drawn out for several months. -
Advice to Management_y: Do not apply

Pros_x: Great People, decent tips most of the time, management stays in the background unless you need help. This place gets a lot of business most of the time (weekends) so their is the potential to make a decent buck. Side-work is manageable. Great money on closing and mid shifts.
Cons_x: Tendency to hire to many people = shift cuts after your 2nd table. Management plays favorites and one has a superiority complex. Typical, if higher than average paying, restaurant jobs with good and bad customers. Due to overstaffing hours tend to be hard to get, especially for new hires. They also tend to overstaff the food-running position so you will be making low to decent pay for running your butt off and closing.
Advice to Management_x: Stop playing favorites, shift cut more proactively.

Title_x: "High volume, very systemized. Can be fun, but also demanding."
Pros_x: Employees received a 20% discount on food and were entitled to free soup and bread always. Co-workers and friendly customers made this job most enjoyable.
Cons_x: I was yelled at and accused by upper management for preparing something improperly, but was only performing in the manner I was trained. The management at some locations is poor/fair.
Advice to Management_x: Not a lot of manager-employee communication. Employees are often poorly trained by fellow employees, but then expected to follow protocol properly.
Pros_y: Good starting salary in-comparison to other companies.. Well designed training program
Cons_y: -Company policy requires only Chefs to work a scheduled 11 hours each shift. -With work demand your not given a scheduled opportunity to take a break at any point. -Typically work 4 of 5 days of a given work-week from 3pm-2am. -Will be relegated to consistently having to attend to scheduled monthly training workshops at 8am after leaving from the night before at 2am. -Provided almost no financial raise for attaining a higher management position. -Executive Chef is given little incentive to promote a manager which ultimately leads to aspiring chefs being drawn out for several months. -

Title_x: "Come for the money, stay for the coworkers"
Pros_x: They offer great health benefits. You are given a lot of opportunities to grow within the company.
Cons_x: Interaction between FOH and BOH wasn't always the best. Servers were not always held responsible for their actions with guests or side work.
Advice to Management_x: Hiring from within the company is a great way to ensure loyalty but there are a lot of other people out there that could give a fresh perspective on how things can and should be done.

Cons_y: -Company policy requires only Chefs to work a scheduled 11 hours each shift. -With work demand your not given a scheduled opportunity to take a break at any point. -Typically work 4 of 5 days of a given work-week from 3pm-2am. -Will be relegated to consistently having to attend to scheduled monthly training workshops at 8am after leaving from the night before at 2am. -Provided almost no financial raise for attaining a higher management position. -Executive Chef is given little incentive to promote a manager which ultimately leads to aspiring chefs being drawn out for several months. -
Advice to Management_y: Do not apply

Title_x: "Come for the money, stay for the coworkers"
Pros_x: They offer great health benefits. You are given a lot of opportunities to grow within the company.
Cons_x: Interaction between FOH and BOH wasn't always the best. Servers were not always held responsible for their actions with guests or side work.
Advice to Management_x: Hiring from within the company is a great way to ensure loyalty but there are a lot of other people out there that could give a fresh perspective on how things can and should be done.

Cons_x: uniform not so pretty, but you also have to deal with rude employees. Depending on your location. This is not true for all of there restaurants. In general great place.

Title_x: "A great company to work for, The Cheesecake Factory sets you up for success."
Pros_x: The food is delicious, so the name and product sell themselves. Management on every level treat you with respect. Great health insurance benefits. Hot Schedules make it easy to request time off, swap shifts, communicate with team. Very fast paced, there is always something to do.
Cons_x: The expectations are very high, so if your standards as an employee are low, don't bother applying.
Advice to Management_x: Keep up the good work! Keep opening restaurants! Keep taking care of us. Keep your expectations high your employees want to deliver good results.

Title_x: "A good job, but very very demanding."
Pros_x: The location I was at was very busy and as a server I made a lot of money. The benefits are... decent. They're the best one is going to get a restaurant. All in all it's a decent place to work.
Cons_x: They will work you into the ground. Consecutive 12+ hour days are common and expected of you. I would get off work at one or 2 in the morning and be expected to return by 10 am. It's a lucrative job if you're willing to invest your life into it.
